text: Praise ye the LORD. Praise, O ye servants of the LORD, praise the name of the LORD.
text_kjv: Praise ye the LORD. Praise, O ye servants of the LORD, praise the name of the LORD.
text_niv: Psalm 113Praise the Lord.Praise, O servants of the Lord,praise the name of the Lord.
text_esv: Praise the LORD! Praise, O servants of the LORD, praise the name of the LORD!
text_nlt: Praise the LORD! Yes, give praise, O servants of the LORD.Praise the name of the LORD!
text_msg: Hallelujah!You who serve God, praise God!Just to speak his name is praise!
text_nasb: Praise the LORD! Praise, O servants of the LORD, Praise the name of the LORD.
context: Psalm 113 initiates the Hallel Psalms (Psalms 113-118), a collection of praises sung during major Jewish festivals like Passover, Shavuot (Weeks), and Sukkot (Tabernacles), as well as during the celebration of Rosh Chodesh (new moon). Understanding its placement is crucial. The Hallel Psalms were not mere additions to the worship service; they were integral to remembering and reliving God's deliverance of Israel from Egypt. They encapsulated themes of liberation, gratitude, and God's enduring faithfulness. During Passover, these psalms were sung in two parts: Psalms 113-114 were sung before the Passover meal, and Psalms 115-118 were sung after. This structure highlighted the journey from slavery to freedom. The term 'servants of the Lord' referred specifically to the Levites, the designated temple workers who led worship, but the call extended to all Israelites who covenanted with God. The 'name of the Lord' wasn't just a label; it represented God's character, attributes, and revealed presence. Praising His name was a way of acknowledging His sovereignty and all that He represented. The repetition of 'Praise' emphasizes the urgency and importance of this act of worship, signifying that praise is not a one-time event but a continuous response to God's character and actions.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 113:1 is a concise yet powerful declaration of God's worthiness of praise and the obligation of His people to offer it. The imperative mood of 'Praise ye the Lord' establishes a command, indicating that praise is not optional for those who identify as servants of the Lord. This opening verse sets the tone for the entire psalm and, by extension, the Hallel Psalms. The phrase 'servants of the Lord' highlights the covenant relationship between God and His people. It acknowledges that believers are not independent entities but rather are bound to God through loyalty, obedience, and gratitude. This service is not burdensome but a privilege born out of love and appreciation for God's grace. 'Praise the name of the Lord' underscores the importance of understanding *who* God is when offering praise. The name of the Lord represents His revealed character, His attributes of holiness, justice, mercy, and power. To praise His name is to acknowledge and celebrate these attributes. The repetition of 'Praise' signals an intensification of worship. It suggests that praise should be persistent, fervent, and all-encompassing. It's a call to engage the whole being – mind, heart, and will – in the act of adoration. This verse also subtly points toward the universality of God's reach. While directed toward 'servants,' it invites all who acknowledge God to join in the chorus of praise. It serves as a reminder that God's glory is meant to be recognized and celebrated by all creation.
application: In modern application, Psalm 113:1 serves as a potent reminder to prioritize praise in our daily lives. We, as believers in Christ, are also 'servants of the Lord,' called to a life of devotion and obedience. This call transcends mere religious observance; it's an invitation to integrate praise into the fabric of our existence. This means intentionally setting aside time each day to focus on God's goodness and express our gratitude. It could involve singing hymns, reading scripture, journaling about His blessings, or simply spending time in quiet contemplation. Critically, the verse challenges us to examine our motivations for praise. Are we praising God out of obligation, or does our praise flow from a genuine love for Him and an awareness of His character? Do we only praise Him when things are going well, or do we consistently acknowledge His sovereignty even in the midst of trials? The phrase 'praise the name of the Lord' encourages us to deepen our understanding of God. As we learn more about His attributes, our praise will become more informed and meaningful. This requires a commitment to studying Scripture, engaging in theological reflection, and seeking to know God more intimately. Practically, we can apply this verse by creating rhythms of praise in our homes, workplaces, and communities. This might involve leading family devotions, sharing testimonies of God's faithfulness with colleagues, or participating in worship services with enthusiasm. Furthermore, recognizing our role as servants of the Lord means aligning our actions with our words. Our lives should reflect the values and character of the God we profess to serve. This includes demonstrating compassion, practicing justice, and extending grace to others. Living a life of praise is about embodying the essence of Psalm 113:1 in every aspect of our being.
prayer: Heavenly Father, You are worthy of all praise and adoration. Forgive me for the times I have neglected to acknowledge Your goodness and Your sovereignty. I confess that I have often been too focused on my own needs and desires to truly see Your hand at work in my life. Lord, help me to cultivate a heart of gratitude and to make praise a constant practice. Teach me to praise Your name – to celebrate Your character and attributes – in all circumstances. May my words and actions reflect my love for You and my commitment to serve You wholeheartedly. I dedicate myself anew to being Your servant, and I ask for Your grace to live a life that is pleasing in Your sight. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: In this context, a 'servant of the Lord' refers to someone who has entered into a covenant relationship with God. This relationship involves acknowledging God's authority, obeying His commands, and serving Him with loyalty and devotion. It's a designation implying both privilege and responsibility, originating from God's choosing, and expressing a life lived in conscious obedience.
faqs.question: Q1: What does it mean to be a 'servant of the Lord' in the context of this verse?

faqs.answer: Praising the 'name' of the Lord is significant because the 'name' represents God's revealed character, attributes, and reputation. It's not just a title, but an encapsulation of all that God is. Praising His name is a way of acknowledging and honoring His specific qualities like holiness, justice, and mercy.
faqs.question: Q2: Why is it important to praise the 'name' of the Lord rather than just praising Him in general?

faqs.answer: Practically, you can integrate praise by setting aside dedicated time for prayer and worship, listening to uplifting music, journaling about God's blessings, and actively looking for opportunities to thank Him throughout the day. Share your faith with others, engage in acts of service, and find ways to worship that bring you closer to God. Gratitude journals are also a helpful tool.
faqs.question: Q3: How can I practically make 'praising the Lord' a more consistent part of my daily life?

faqs.answer: Yes, even if you don't feel like praising God, you should still choose to do so. Praise is an act of the will, not just an emotion. By choosing to praise God even when you don't feel like it, you are affirming His worthiness and submitting your feelings to His authority. Often, feelings follow action; consistent praise can cultivate genuine joy.
faqs.question: Q4: What if I don't 'feel' like praising God? Should I still do it?

faqs.answer: Psalm 113:1 echoes the call to praise found throughout the Bible. It aligns with passages like Psalm 150, which urges all creation to praise God, and passages in Revelation that depict heavenly beings constantly worshipping God. It reinforces the idea that praise is a fundamental response to God's character and actions.
